paragraphs.text:
%md

# Machine Learning Example -- Regression

**NOTE: UNIFNISHED**

<ralph.schlosser@gmail.com>

## Introduction

The following code will demonstrate how to apply:

* Simple linear regression
* LASSO
* Random Forests
* Support Vector Machines


to perform regression analysis on a supervised learning problem.

For each of these, we'll do splitting of the data into training and tests sets, so we can run Cross Validation.

result.msg:
Machine Learning Example – Regression

NOTE: UNIFNISHED

ralph.schlosser@gmail.com

Introduction

The following code will demonstrate how to apply:

  • Simple linear regression
  • LASSO
  • Random Forests
  • Support Vector Machines

to perform regression analysis on a supervised learning problem.

For each of these, we'll do splitting of the data into training and tests sets, so we can run Cross Validation.

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Prerequisites

First we're loading some libs and define helper functions.

For this example, I'm using `scikit-learn` (<http://scikit-learn.org/stable/>).

result.msg:
Prerequisites

First we're loading some libs and define helper functions.

For this example, I'm using scikit-learn (http://scikit-learn.org/stable/).

paragraphs.text:
%python import os import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import StringIO from sklearn import datasets from pandas import Series, DataFrame import pandas as pd import numpy as np # The below is necessary to use matplotlib from Zeppelin. plt.rcdefaults() plt.switch_backend('agg') os.system("export DISPLAY=:0") # Display the plot result inline. def show(p): img = StringIO.StringIO() p.savefig(img, format='svg') img.seek(0) print "%html
" + img.buf + "
"

%md

### Data Set

We're going to be using a built-in data set from the `sklearn` package.

This data set was originally taken from Efron et al (2004) "Least Angle Regression," Annals of Statistics (with discussion), 407-499: <https://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0406456.pdf>

### Description

The following features are available:

* Age
* Sex
* Body mass index
* Average blood pressure
* Six blood serum measurements

The response variable (y) is the a measure of disease progression.

#### Loading the data
Let's first load the data and describe the resulting data frame:

result.msg:
Data Set

We're going to be using a built-in data set from the sklearn package.

This data set was originally taken from Efron et al (2004) “Least Angle Regression,” Annals of Statistics (with discussion), 407-499: https://arxiv.org/pdf/math/0406456.pdf

Description

The following features are available:

  • Age
  • Sex
  • Body mass index
  • Average blood pressure
  • Six blood serum measurements

The response variable (y) is the a measure of disease progression.

Loading the data

Let's first load the data and describe the resulting data frame:

paragraphs.text:
%python

diabetes = datasets.load_diabetes()

# Note that this has two parts data and target
X_raw = DataFrame(diabetes.data,columns=['age','sex','bmi','bp','S1','S2','S3','S4','S5','S6'])
X_raw.describe()

%md 

#### Standardize

As a next step, we'll standardize the data and also look at the response variable.

result.msg:
Standardize

As a next step, we'll standardize the data and also look at the response variable.

paragraphs.text:
%python

X_raw_std = (X_raw - X_raw.mean()) / X_raw.std()
y = Series(diabetes.target)
y.describe()

%md

### Exploratory Analysis: Scatter plots

To get a first glimpse of the correlations structure, let's do some scatter plots.

result.msg:
Exploratory Analysis: Scatter plots

To get a first glimpse of the correlations structure, let's do some scatter plots.

paragraphs.text:
%python

# Let's do a scatter matrix
# Note that none of these have been standardised.
scatter = pd.scatter_matrix(X_raw) # Some very correlated, one almost looks binary

#show(scatter[1])

%md

Now, why don't we  add 100 noise columns to make the regression a bit harder! :)

result.msg: Now, why don't we add 100 noise columns to make the regression a bit harder! :)

paragraphs.text:
%python

# Add 100 columns of random noise columns at the end to make it harder
np.random.seed(123)
X = X_raw.join(DataFrame(np.random.randn(len(y), 100)))

%md

#### Create training and test sets

As is best-practice, we'll split up the data into training and test sets. We'll be using an approximate 75% for training / 25% for test set split.

result.msg:
Create training and test sets

As is best-practice, we'll split up the data into training and test sets. We'll be using an approximate 75% for training / 25% for test set split.

paragraphs.text:
%python

# Creates a test data set and drops the original index.
np.random.seed(123)
train_size = 332
train_select = np.random.permutation(range(len(y)))
X_train = X.ix[train_select[:train_size], :].reset_index(drop=True)
X_test = X.ix[train_select[train_size:], :].reset_index(drop=True)
y_train = y[train_select[:train_size]].reset_index(drop=True)
y_test = y[train_select[train_size:]].reset_index(drop=True)

%md

### Warm-up: Simple Linear Regression

Nothing fancy here, just simple linear regression, just to see how well we'll do.

result.msg:
Warm-up: Simple Linear Regression

Nothing fancy here, just simple linear regression, just to see how well we'll do.

paragraphs.text:
%python

from sklearn import linear_model
reg = linear_model.LinearRegression()
reg.fit(X_train, y_train)

result.msg: LinearRegression(copy_X=True, fit_intercept=True, n_jobs=1, normalize=False)

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Predicting on the test data and plots

Now, with the generated regression model, we can see how well we can predict the test data.

The plot doesn't look too bad.

result.msg:
Predicting on the test data and plots

Now, with the generated regression model, we can see how well we can predict the test data.

The plot doesn't look too bad.

paragraphs.text:
%python

reg_test_pred = reg.predict(X_test)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
fig = plt.figure()
plt.plot(y_test,reg_test_pred,'kx')
plt.plot(plt.xlim(), plt.ylim(), ls="--")

show(plt)

%md

#### Model assessment

Now it's time to assess our model performance.

result.msg:
Model assessment

Now it's time to assess our model performance.

paragraphs.text:
%python

RSS_reg = np.mean(pow((reg_test_pred - y_test), 2))
print(RSS_reg)

%python

res = reg.fit(X_raw_std, y)
print res.score(X_raw_std, y)

X = X_raw_std
y = Series(diabetes.target)
train_size = 332
train_select = range(len(y))
X_train = X.ix[train_select[:train_size],:].reset_index(drop=True)
X_test = X.ix[train_select[train_size:],:].reset_index(drop=True)
y_train = y[train_select[:train_size]].reset_index(drop=True)
y_test = y[train_select[train_size:]].reset_index(drop=True)
y_hat = reg.predict(X_test)
MSe = np.mean(pow((y_hat - y_test), 2))

print(MSe)

%md

### LASSO Regression

Next, we're going to repeat the analysis using LASSO.

result.msg:
LASSO Regression

Next, we're going to repeat the analysis using LASSO.

paragraphs.text:
%python

# Let's reset data.
np.random.seed(123)
X = X_raw.join(DataFrame(np.random.randn(len(y), 100)))

# Create a training and test set of size 332 and 110 (approx 75%/25% split)
train_size = 332
np.random.seed(123)
train_select = np.random.permutation(range(len(y)))
X_train = X.ix[train_select[:train_size], :].reset_index(drop=True)
X_test = X.ix[train_select[train_size:], :].reset_index(drop=True)
y_train = y[train_select[:train_size]].reset_index(drop=True)
y_test = y[train_select[train_size:]].reset_index(drop=True)

%md

The idea is to minimize the residual sum of squares with respect to a constraint (cost).

result.msg: The idea is to minimize the residual sum of squares with respect to a constraint (cost).

paragraphs.text:
%python

lasso = linear_model.LassoCV(cv = 10)
lasso.fit(X_train, y_train)
lasso.coef_

lasso_test_pred = lasso.predict(X_test)

fig = plt.figure()
plt.plot(y_test,lasso_test_pred,'kx')
plt.plot(plt.xlim(), plt.ylim(), ls="--")

%md 

#### Model assessment


LASSO results:

result.msg:
Model assessment

LASSO results:

paragraphs.text:
%python

show(plt)

RSS_lasso = np.mean(pow((lasso_test_pred - y_test), 2))

%md

### Support Vector Machines

This example shows that SVMs perform poorly.

result.msg:
Support Vector Machines

This example shows that SVMs perform poorly.

paragraphs.text:
%python

# Support vector machines/regression
from sklearn import svm
my_svm = svm.SVR()
my_svm.fit(X_train, y_train) 

# Predict
svm_test_pred = my_svm.predict(X_test)

# Plot
fig = plt.figure()
plt.plot(y_test,svm_test_pred, 'kx')
plt.plot(plt.xlim(), plt.ylim(), ls="--")

# Performance 
RSS_svm = np.mean(pow((svm_test_pred - y_test), 2))

print(RSS_svm)

result.msg:
SVR(C=1.0, cache_size=200, coef0=0.0, degree=3, epsilon=0.1, gamma='auto',
  kernel='rbf', max_iter=-1, shrinking=True, tol=0.001, verbose=False)
  [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x7feed18026d0>]
[<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x7feed18114d0>]
 5808.52234497

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Random Forest Regression

result.msg: Random Forest Regression

paragraphs.text:
%python

from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
rf = RandomForestRegressor()
rf.fit(X_train, y_train) 

# Predict
rf_test_pred = rf.predict(X_test)

# Plot
fig = plt.figure()
plt.plot(y_test,rf_test_pred, 'kx')
plt.plot(plt.xlim(), plt.ylim(), ls="--")

# Performance 
RSS_rf = np.mean(pow((rf_test_pred - y_test), 2))
print(RSS_rf)

result.msg:
RandomForestRegressor(bootstrap=True, criterion='mse', max_depth=None,
           max_features='auto', max_leaf_nodes=None,
           min_impurity_split=1e-07, min_samples_leaf=1,
           min_samples_split=2, min_weight_fraction_leaf=0.0,
           n_estimators=10, n_jobs=1, oob_score=False, random_state=None,
           verbose=0, warm_start=False)
  [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x7feed1604e50>]
[<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x7feed1628ed0>]
